Data Types

In TJS2, variables do not have "types," but they do have types internally. Rather than saying they have no types, it is more accurate to say that types are handled automatically and dynamically.
The internal types include void, Integer, Real, String, Object, and Octet sequence types.

void

void represents that nothing is expressed (its meaning is different from JavaScript). Variables that have just been declared are void.
The === (identity) operator is used for comparisons between void values.
The typeof operator returns "void" for this type.

Integer Type

TJS2 can handle 64-bit precision integers as the integer type. Integers are usually treated as signed integers, but the sole exception is the >>> operator, which treats the left-hand side as an unsigned integer.
The typeof operator returns "Integer" for this type.

Real Type

TJS2 can handle 64-bit precision real numbers (double-precision real numbers) as the real type.
The typeof operator returns "Real" for this type.

String Type

TJS2 can handle null-terminated strings with no length limit. A null-terminated string means that the string is handled assuming it ends with \0.
Character codes are handled as wide characters (usually UNICODE), but whether they are 16-bit or 32-bit wide characters depends on the environment in which TJS2 was compiled. For example, it is 16-bit on Windows, but 32-bit on Solaris or Linux.
The typeof operator returns "String" for this type.

Object Type

The Object type is a type that holds objects. In addition to objects allocated with the new operator, functions, classes, property objects, etc., are all of the object type.
The typeof operator returns "Object" for this type.

Unlike TJS or JavaScript, TJS2's object type internally holds two pointers: a pointer to the object itself and a pointer to the object that should serve as its context, enabling the implementation of so-called closures. The operator used to change this context portion is the incontextof operator.

Octet Sequence Type

The Octet sequence type is a type for handling 8-bit wide data sequences (octet sequences). it is primarily a type for handling binary data.
The typeof operator returns "Octet" for this type.
